etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'install'. 'Install' comes from Old French 'installer', from Medieval Latin 'installare' (to place in a position).

senses.def: To install something again, especially after it has been removed or has stopped working.
senses.ex: After the system crashed, we had to re-install all the software from scratch.

senses.def: To restore someone to a former position of authority or power.
senses.ex: The court ruling ordered the mayor to be re-installed in his office.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'instaurare' (to renew, restore).

senses.def: To restore someone to a former position, rank, or condition.
senses.ex: The court ordered the company to reinstate the employee after finding the dismissal unlawful.

senses.def: To bring back into use or effect; to re-establish.
senses.ex: After the renovations, the library was able to reinstate its popular summer reading program.

etymology: From re- + reinstatement, from Middle English 'reinstaten', from Old French 'restaurer' (to restore), from Latin 'restaurare', from 're-' (again) + 'staurare' (to set up, to build).

senses.def: The act or process of restoring someone or something to a previous position, status, condition, or use.
senses.ex: Following the review, the board approved the re-instatement of the executive to her former role.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'instituere' (to set up, establish).

senses.def: To establish or put back into effect, or to restore someone or something to a former position or condition.
senses.ex: After the review, the board voted to reinstitute the old funding model.

etymology: From re- + insurance, from Old French assurance, from medieval Latin assecurantia, from assecurare 'make secure'.

senses.def: An agreement or practice whereby one insurance company transfers part of its risks to another company, which in turn agrees to indemnify the first company against all or part of the loss.
senses.ex: The airline purchased re-insurance to cover potential losses from the grounding of its fleet.

etymology: From prefix 're-' (again) + 'integrate' (to make whole, unite). First attested in early 20th century.

senses.def: To restore to a state of unity, wholeness, or functionality, especially after a period of separation, illness, disruption, or exclusion.
senses.ex: The rehabilitation program helped the former addict re-integrate into society and reconnect with his family.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'interre' (to bury).

senses.def: To bury or place something back into the ground or a similar position, especially after exhumation or removal.
senses.ex: After the forensic examination was complete, they prepared to re-inter the victim's body with full honors.

etymology: From prefix 're-' (again) + 'interview'. 'Interview' derives from French 'entrevue', from 'entrevoir' ('to see each other briefly').

senses.def: To interview someone again, especially for a second time regarding the same matter or position.
senses.ex: The producers decided to re-interview the finalists to assess their chemistry for the reality show.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'introduce' (from Latin 'introducere', to lead in).

senses.def: To introduce something or someone again, especially after a period of absence or removal.
senses.ex: The committee voted to re-introduce the bill in the next legislative session.

senses.def: To make someone or something familiar with a place, situation, or activity again.
senses.ex: After her long illness, she needed time to re-introduce herself to the demands of her job.

senses.def: To bring a species back to an area where it once lived.
senses.ex: Conservationists are working to re-introduce wolves into Yellowstone National Park.

etymology: From re- 'again' + introduction.

senses.def: The act of introducing something or someone again, whether a person to another, a subject for renewed consideration, or a species into its former habitat.
senses.ex: The re-introduction of the lion to the park was met with cautious optimism by conservationists.

etymology: From re- 'again' + invent, from Latin invenire 'to find, discover'.

senses.def: To create, design, or introduce something new, often significantly improving or altering it; to discover or establish something that has already been discovered or established, particularly when doing so unnecessarily.
senses.ex: The team hopes to re-invent urban transportation with their new electric scooter.

etymology: From re- 'again' + invest.

senses.def: To invest money, resources, or qualities in something again, or to grant power or authority once more.
senses.ex: Following the sale of the property, they planned to re-invest the capital into expanding their business.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + investigate, from Latin investigare 'to trace out, discover'.

senses.def: To investigate something again, especially if new information has surfaced or to re-examine previous conclusions.
senses.ex: The detective had to re-investigate the cold case after a witness came forward with a crucial detail.

etymology: From re- + investigation, from Latin investigatio, from investigare 'to investigate'.

senses.def: The act of investigating something again, especially after an initial investigation has been completed.
senses.ex: The committee called for a re-investigation into the company's financial dealings.

etymology: From re- 'again' + invigorate, from Latin invīgorāre 'to give strength'.

senses.def: To give new energy, strength, or life to something or someone, making it or them more lively, active, or effective.
senses.ex: The surprise visit from the CEO re-invigorated the entire department's morale and productivity.

etymology: From re- 'again' + isolation (1650s, 'act of setting apart'), from Latin 'insulatus', past participle of 'insulare' ('to make an island').

senses.def: The act or process of isolating or separating something or someone again, or the state of being so separated.
senses.ex: The sudden re-isolation of the town caused significant disruption to supply chains.

etymology: From re- 'again' + issue, from Old French escalle 'a going out, an exit', from escir 'to go out, issue'.

senses.def: To put out, release, or publish something again, such as a document, recording, or publication.
senses.ex: The company plans to re-issue the popular board game with updated rules and artwork.

senses.def: An instance or item of something being put out or released again.
senses.ex: We received a re-issue of our building permit with a revised expiration date.

etymology: From Latin 'iterare' (to repeat), from 'iterum' (again). First attested in English in the early 17th century.

senses.def: To say or do something again, especially for emphasis or clarity, or to repeat a process or action.
senses.ex: The politician chose to reiterate his campaign promises during the final televised debate.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'jig' (to move up and down quickly, to dance). The sense of 'adjust' likely developed from the idea of making small, quick adjustments.

senses.def: To adjust or rearrange something, such as a plan, system, or piece of equipment, in order to improve it or make it work better.
senses.ex: We need to re-jig the marketing strategy to target a younger audience more effectively.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + join (verb). From Middle English joinen, from Old French joindre, from Latin iungere ('to join').

senses.def: To connect or become connected again, either physically or by resuming membership in a group, after a period of separation or interruption.
senses.ex: After the temporary closure, the two sections of the bridge were re-joined, allowing traffic to resume.

etymology: From 're-' (prefix meaning 'again') + 'key'.

senses.def: To change the key of a musical composition or a musical instrument.
senses.ex: The composer decided to re-key the symphony in a minor key to evoke a darker mood.

senses.def: To re-enter or reassign data, especially in a system that uses keys for identification or access.
senses.ex: We need to re-key all the customer accounts after the database migration.

senses.def: To change the combination of a lock.
senses.ex: The landlord had to re-key the apartment locks for the new tenants.

etymology: From Middle English 'rekendelen', from Old English 'recendelian', from 're-' (again) + 'cendelian' (to kindle).

senses.def: To cause something to become active, enthusiastic, or alive again, such as a fire, feeling, or relationship.
senses.ex: After the long pause, the politician's impassioned speech seemed to re-kindle the crowd's excitement.

senses.def: To ignite or set fire to something again.
senses.ex: The campers worked for an hour to re-kindle the damp wood into a roaring fire.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + launch (verb).

senses.def: To introduce or send out again, especially after a pause in activity, a period of failure, or for a second attempt.
senses.ex: Following the setback, the team worked tirelessly to re-launch the project with renewed vigor.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + lay (verb).

senses.def: To place, spread, install, or transmit something again, especially over a surface or through a channel.
senses.ex: The workers had to re-lay the carpet after the flood damaged the original installation.

senses.def: To lay eggs again.
senses.ex: It took several weeks for the hen to re-lay following the disruption.

etymology: From re- (prefix indicating repetition or return) + learn.

senses.def: To learn something again, either after forgetting it or after a period of disuse, or to acquire new knowledge that replaces or modifies previous understanding.
senses.ex: After her injury, the athlete had to re-learn how to perform the complex movements of her sport.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb let 'to lease, rent'.

senses.def: To lease or rent out a property again after a previous tenancy has ended.
senses.ex: The landlord hoped to re-let the vacant office space by the end of the month.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + line (verb). The sense of drawing lines is older, while the sense of inserting lining material developed later, possibly influenced by the noun 'lining'.

senses.def: To draw, mark, or place a new line or boundary, or to adjust something into a new line or position.
senses.ex: The artist had to re-line the sketch to correct the perspective before adding color.

senses.def: To insert new lining material into something.
senses.ex: She decided to re-line the antique jacket with silk to restore its original elegance.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + litigate, from Latin litigatus, past participle of litigare 'to dispute, contend', from lis, litis 'lawsuit, dispute'.

senses.def: To bring legal action again on a matter that has already been decided or settled, or to debate or argue about a past issue as if it were a new dispute.
senses.ex: The company sought to re-litigate the settled contract terms, causing further legal entanglements.

etymology: From the prefix 're-' meaning 'again' + the verb 'live'.

senses.def: To experience a past event, memory, or feeling again, often as vividly as if it were happening in the present.
senses.ex: He often found himself re-living that moment of triumph on the stage.

etymology: From prefix re- + verb load. Load is from Middle English loaden, from Old English lād ('way, journey, burden'), from Proto-Germanic *laidō.

senses.def: To load something again, especially a weapon, after it has been fired or emptied.
senses.ex: The soldier had to re-load his rifle quickly to defend the position.

senses.def: To load a digital file, webpage, or application again into a computer's memory.
senses.ex: If the page doesn't load properly, try to re-load it by pressing F5.

senses.def: To load a vehicle or container again.
senses.ex: The dockworkers began to re-load the ship with cargo for its return journey.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again, back) + 'locare' (to place), from 'locus' (place).

senses.def: To move oneself or something else to a new place or location; to establish or find a new position for someone or something.
senses.ex: The company will re-locate its headquarters to a more accessible downtown area.

etymology: From re- + location, from Latin 'locus' ('place').

senses.def: The act or process of moving oneself or something else to a new place, position, or site.
senses.ex: The re-location of the office required careful planning for all departments.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb lock.

senses.def: To secure something again with a lock, especially after it has been opened or unlocked.
senses.ex: He remembered to re-lock the bicycle after borrowing it for a short ride.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + make.

senses.def: To construct, create, or perform something again, often with alterations or improvements, or to produce a new version of an existing work.
senses.ex: The studio plans to re-make the popular 1980s television series with a new generation of actors.

etymology: From prefix re- + map. First attested in the early 20th century.

senses.def: To map, chart, or plan an area, subject, or system again, often incorporating new information, a changed perspective, or a new configuration.
senses.ex: Scientists plan to re-map the ocean floor to identify new species.

etymology: From re- (Latin prefix meaning 'again') + mark (Old English 'ge)marc, from Proto-Germanic '*markō', related to 'merc' meaning 'boundary'.

senses.def: To mark something again, or to add new marks to something that has already been marked.
senses.ex: The teacher had to re-mark the exam papers after discovering a grading error.

senses.def: To comment on or discuss something again.
senses.ex: He paused to re-mark on the surprising lack of public interest in the event.

senses.def: To notice or observe something again.
senses.ex: She re-marked the subtle shift in his demeanor, which she had initially overlooked.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + marry.

senses.def: To marry again, either to a new spouse after a previous marriage has ended, or to a former spouse.
senses.ex: The widower vowed that he would never re-marry, but found love again years later.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + melt.

senses.def: To melt a substance again after it has solidified.
senses.ex: The glassblower would re-melt the cooled material to shape it into a vase.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + mix (verb).

senses.def: To combine or alter elements again, especially to create a new or modified version of a piece of music or a mixture.
senses.ex: The producer plans to re-mix the classic album with updated sound quality.

etymology: From 're-' (prefix denoting repetition or reversal) + 'model' (to shape, form, design). First attested in the early 19th century.

senses.def: To change the structure or form of something, especially to improve it or make it more suitable for a new purpose.
senses.ex: The team will re-model the existing software to incorporate advanced security features.

etymology: From 're-' (prefix meaning 'again') + 'modularise'. 'Modularise' comes from 'module', from French 'module', from Latin 'modulus' (a small measure).

senses.def: To reorganize a system, structure, or process by breaking it down into distinct modules or components and reassembling them, often to improve flexibility or efficiency.
senses.ex: The team decided to re-modularise the entire workflow to better adapt to changing market demands.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + mortgage (noun, verb).

senses.def: To take out a new mortgage on a property that already has a mortgage, often to borrow more money.
senses.ex: Many homeowners are choosing to re-mortgage their properties to take advantage of lower interest rates.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + name (verb), from Old English nama, from Proto-Germanic *namô.

senses.def: To assign a new name to someone or something, often following a change in identity, status, or classification.
senses.ex: After the merger, the company decided to re-name its flagship product.

etymology: From re- 'again' + nationalize, from national (adj.) 'of a nation', from nation (n.) 'nation', from Latin natio 'birth, race, class, nation', from natus 'born'.

senses.def: To transfer ownership or control of an industry, company, or asset from private to public or national hands again, especially after a period of privatization or foreign ownership.
senses.ex: The new administration promised to re-nationalize key utilities that had been sold off decades earlier.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'negotiate', from Latin 'negotiatus', past participle of 'negotiari' (to trade, carry on business), from 'negōtium' (business, trouble, affair), from 'nec' (not) + 'ōtium' (leisure).

senses.def: To discuss and attempt to reach a new agreement or understanding about something previously settled, especially after circumstances have changed or a previous deal has been made.
senses.ex: Following the economic downturn, the company sought to re-negotiate its loan terms with the bank.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'nominare' (to name), from 'nomen' (name).

senses.def: To name or put forward someone or something for a position or honor again.
senses.ex: The committee voted to re-nominate the chairperson for another term after her successful first year.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + number, from Middle English nombre, from Old French nombre, from Latin numerus.

senses.def: To assign new numbers to items in a sequence, typically because items have been added, removed, or rearranged.
senses.ex: The teacher had to re-number the student worksheets after several were misplaced.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'occupy' (to take possession of, inhabit). From Middle English 'occupien', from Old French 'occuper', from Latin 'occupare' (to take possession of, seize).

senses.def: To occupy or take possession of a place, position, or dwelling again after a period of absence, vacancy, or loss.
senses.ex: Following the conflict's resolution, the nation worked to re-occupy its disputed territories.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'occurrere' (to run up, meet, happen).

senses.def: To happen again or come back to mind.
senses.ex: The strange dream began to re-occur with unsettling frequency.

etymology: From 're-' (prefix meaning 'again') + 'offend' (to commit an illegal act or transgress).

senses.def: To commit an illegal act, or an unacceptable or wrong behavior again, especially after having been previously punished or warned.
senses.ex: Many rehabilitation programs aim to reduce the likelihood that former inmates will re-offend after their release.

etymology: From re- (Latin prefix meaning 'again') + offer (Old French 'offrir', from Latin 'offerre' meaning 'to bring to, present').

senses.def: To offer something again, especially after it has been refused, rejected, or requires renewed consideration.
senses.ex: The airline decided to re-offer the discounted flight tickets to the public after the initial sale fell short of expectations.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb open. Middle English open, from Old English open, from Proto-Germanic *opana-.

senses.def: To open again something that was previously closed.
senses.ex: The museum will re-open its doors to the public next month after extensive renovations.

senses.def: To begin or resume an activity, discussion, or process that had been stopped.
senses.ex: The committee decided to re-open the investigation into the financial irregularities.

senses.def: To cause a wound or injury to become open again.
senses.ex: He accidentally re-opened the stitches on his leg while playing sports too soon.

etymology: From re- + orchestration; from French orchestrer (to orchestrate), from orchestre (orchestra).

senses.def: The act or process of arranging or organizing something again, especially a musical composition for different instruments or style, or a new structure or approach for a non-musical entity.
senses.ex: The conductor praised the careful re-orchestration of the opera for the smaller venue.

etymology: From Middle English re- (prefix meaning 'again') + order (verb, noun), from Old French ordre, from Latin ordo.

senses.def: To arrange again, especially by issuing a new command or placing a new request for goods or services.
senses.ex: After the unexpected surge in demand, the company had to re-order the supplies immediately.

etymology: From re- + ordering, from order, from Old French ordre, from Latin ōrdō, ōrdinis, from Proto-Indo-European *ar- 'to fit together'.

senses.def: The act or result of arranging something again, especially in a different or more effective sequence.
senses.ex: The team implemented a re-ordering of tasks to meet the new deadline.

etymology: From re- + organisation. Organisation derives from Latin organizare, from organum ('organ, instrument').

senses.def: The process or result of organizing something again, especially to improve efficiency or change its structure.
senses.ex: The firm underwent a significant reorganisation to streamline its operations.

etymology: From re- 'again' + organise. First attested in the early 20th century.

senses.def: To change the structure, arrangement, or management of something, especially an organization or a system, often to improve its efficiency or effectiveness, or to adapt to new circumstances.
senses.ex: The management team was tasked with re-organising the entire distribution network.

etymology: From re- + organization. Ultimately from Greek organon ('tool, instrument, organ').

senses.def: The action or process of organizing something again, or the new structure or arrangement that results from this.
senses.ex: The committee's re-organization aimed to improve its decision-making process.

etymology: From prefix 're-' (again) + 'organize'. 'Organize' derives from Greek 'organon', meaning 'tool, instrument, organ'.

senses.def: To change the structure, arrangement, or operation of something, typically to improve efficiency or adapt to new circumstances.
senses.ex: The committee decided to re-organize the entire department's workflow for better productivity.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'orientare' (to place eastward; to position), from 'oriens' (rising), past participle of 'oriri' (to rise).

senses.def: To adjust one's position or bearings, or to cause someone or something to do so, especially in relation to a new or unfamiliar environment, situation, or perspective.
senses.ex: The travelers took a moment to re-orient themselves after arriving in the bustling city center.

senses.def: To change the focus, direction, or purpose of something, such as an organization or a project.
senses.ex: The committee's primary goal was to re-orient the research towards practical applications.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'orientate' (to determine one's position relative to the east, or to align oneself). 'Orientate' comes from Latin 'oriens' (rising), referring to the east.

senses.def: To adjust one's position, direction, thinking, or behavior, especially to adapt to new surroundings, circumstances, or a new perspective.
senses.ex: After moving to a new city, he spent several weeks re-orientating himself to the local customs and traffic patterns.

senses.def: To cause someone or something to adjust its position, direction, or perspective.
senses.ex: The consultant helped re-orientate the company's strategy to address the evolving market demands.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'oxygenate' (to supply with oxygen). 'Oxygenate' derives from 'oxygen', from Greek 'oxys' (sharp, acid) + 'genēs' (producer).

senses.def: To supply something with oxygen again, especially after it has become depleted.
senses.ex: The therapist had to re-oxygenate the patient's lungs during the difficult breathing exercises.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + package (verb).

senses.def: To put something into a new or different package, or to present or organize it in a new way, often to improve its appeal or clarity.
senses.ex: The marketing team decided to re-package the old software with a modern interface and new features.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + paint, from Middle English peynte, from Old French peindre, from Latin pingere 'to paint'.

senses.def: To paint something again, especially to refresh or change its appearance.
senses.ex: After the storm damaged the fence, they had to re-paint the entire structure.

senses.def: To depict or portray something anew, often with a different perspective or emphasis.
senses.ex: The documentary sought to re-paint the historical figure's legacy for a modern audience.

etymology: From Old French 'repairer' (to go back, return, resort to), from Latin 're-' (back) + 'pāre' (to prepare, make ready). The sense of 'to mend' developed in Middle English from the idea of restoring something to its former state.

senses.def: To restore something broken, damaged, or faulty to good working order or condition; to mend or remedy; to make amends for.
senses.ex: The artisan carefully repaired the antique vase, making it look as good as new.

senses.def: To go or resort to a place.
senses.ex: After the day's work, the weary travelers decided to repair to the quiet village for supper.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + palletize, from pallet (noun), from Old French palete 'small spade, board', diminutive of pal 'stake'.

senses.def: To arrange items on a pallet in a new configuration, which may involve transferring them to a different pallet or simply reorganizing their placement.
senses.ex: Damaged goods were removed and the remaining inventory had to be re-palletized before shipment.

etymology: From re- + pass. From Middle English 'repasse', from Old French 'repasser'.

senses.def: To pass over, through, by, or again; to elapse or go by again; to review or reconsider.
senses.ex: The reviewer had to re-pass the manuscript to check for errors.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + people (verb, 'to inhabit').

senses.def: To populate or repopulate an area with people.
senses.ex: The government hoped to re-people the abandoned villages after the war.

senses.def: To provide a place or organization with new or additional staff.
senses.ex: The company plans to re-people its marketing department with fresh talent.

etymology: From Latin 're-' meaning 'again' + 'photograph', from Greek 'phos' (light) + 'graphein' (to write).

senses.def: To photograph something again, whether to improve a previous attempt, capture a new aspect, or reproduce an existing image.
senses.ex: The museum decided to re-photograph the entire collection to update their digital records.

etymology: From re- + phrase, from Middle English *frase*, from Old French *frase* 'phrase, manner of speech', from Latin *phrasis* 'diction, way of speaking', from Greek *phrasis* 'speech, remark, expression'.

senses.def: To express something again in a different way, typically to clarify, simplify, or adjust for a specific audience or context.
senses.ex: She had to rephrase the complex technical explanation for the general public.

etymology: From Old French 'replacer', from 're-' (again) + 'placer' (to place).

senses.def: To put something back in its original position.
senses.ex: After the inspection, the technician carefully replaced the panel.

senses.def: To take the place of someone or something; to substitute.
senses.ex: The new software will replace the outdated system by the end of the year.

senses.def: To provide a replacement for something that has been lost, stolen, or damaged.
senses.ex: The insurance company agreed to replace the stolen jewelry.

senses.def: To put a new person in a job or position.
senses.ex: The company decided to replace the manager with someone more experienced.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + plan, from Middle French plan, from Latin planum 'a flat surface'.

senses.def: To plan again or make a revised plan, especially after previous plans proved inadequate or circumstances changed.
senses.ex: The team had to re-plan their marketing strategy when sales figures unexpectedly dropped.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'plantare' (to plant).

senses.def: To place something in the ground again, or establish it in a new place, especially after it has been removed, damaged, or displaced.
senses.ex: The landscapers will re-plant the shrubs that were damaged during construction.

senses.def: To transplant a body part, such as a finger or organ, back into its original position or into a new location.
senses.ex: Microsurgeons worked for hours to re-plant the child's accidentally severed thumb.

etymology: From prefix re- ('again, back') + verb point ('to aim, direct, sharpen, indicate'). The meaning of directing again is attested from the 17th century, and sharpening again from the 19th century.

senses.def: To adjust the direction or focus of something, or to restore or renew its point or tip.
senses.ex: The engineer had to re-point the telescope to track the newly discovered comet.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'pausare' (to pause, rest).

senses.def: To place or arrange something again, or to present an idea or theory again for consideration.
senses.ex: The artist decided to re-pose the sculpture on a different pedestal, hoping it would look more striking.

senses.def: To rest or relax after exertion or illness.
senses.ex: Following the surgery, the patient was advised to re-pose for at least a week.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'positionem' (position).

senses.def: To place or arrange something again in a different or more suitable position.
senses.ex: The paramedics had to re-position the patient carefully onto the stretcher.

senses.def: To change the way one thinks about or understands something.
senses.ex: After the crisis, the company had to re-position its entire marketing strategy.

senses.def: To move into a new or different role or place in society or a profession.
senses.ex: She decided to re-position herself in the industry as a consultant rather than an employee.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + possess, from Old French possesser, from Latin possidere 'to own, to have power over'.

senses.def: To take back possession of something, especially after it has been taken away or lost.
senses.ex: The bank had to re-possess the car when the owner defaulted on the loan payments.

senses.def: To regain control or mastery over something, such as a feeling or ability.
senses.ex: After a period of illness, she worked hard to re-possess her former strength and energy.

senses.def: To occupy or inhabit a place again.
senses.ex: The rebels managed to re-possess the town after a fierce battle with government forces.

etymology: From re- 'again' + possession, from Old French possession, from Latin possessionem (nominative possessio) 'a holding, ownership', from possidere 'to own, possess'.

senses.def: The act or process of regaining ownership or control of something, especially property previously held or owned, after a default or legal dispute.
senses.ex: The bank initiated re-possession after the borrower failed to make payments on the house.

etymology: From re- + pot. Pot is from Middle English pot, from Old French pot, from Late Latin potus ('drinking vessel').

senses.def: To place something, especially a plant, into a new pot or container, often with fresh soil or other material.
senses.ex: She decided to re-pot the wilting basil plant into a larger ceramic container with fresh potting mix.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + present (verb).

senses.def: To present something again or anew, or to formally introduce someone or something anew, including making a formal objection or appeal.
senses.ex: The committee will re-present its findings to the board next week.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'praesentare' (to place before, to present).

senses.def: The act of presenting something again, in a new way, or introducing someone; this includes revised depictions, performances, or formal introductions.
senses.ex: The team's re-presentation of the project proposal highlighted their innovative approach to market challenges.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + print (verb).

senses.def: To print something again, especially a book, article, or document, possibly with revisions or updates.
senses.ex: The university decided to re-print the esteemed professor's seminal work for a new generation of students.

etymology: From re- + prioritisation; prioritisation from prioritise, from priority, from Old French priorite, from Late Latin prioritat-, prioritas, from Latin prior 'former'.

senses.def: The act or process of establishing a new order of importance or urgency for a set of tasks, items, or goals.
senses.ex: The committee initiated a re-prioritisation of its long-term development projects following the strategic review.

etymology: From 're-' (prefix meaning 'again') + 'process' (verb). The verb 'process' itself comes from Middle English 'proces', from Old French 'proces', meaning 'a course, a proceeding', ultimately from Latin 'processus', the past participle of 'procedere' ('to go forth, advance').

senses.def: To process something again, especially after an initial attempt has failed or to improve the result.
senses.ex: The lab had to re-process the samples when the initial analysis yielded inconclusive data.

senses.def: To process raw materials or waste materials again to extract usable substances or prepare them for further use.
senses.ex: Recycling plants re-process aluminum cans to create new products.

senses.def: To re-examine or re-evaluate information or data, often with new perspectives or methods.
senses.ex: The committee decided to re-process the historical records to uncover any overlooked details.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'producere' (to bring forth, produce).

senses.def: To create a copy or likeness of something.
senses.ex: The artist meticulously tried to reproduce the original painting's texture and color.

senses.def: To produce offspring or new individuals of the same kind.
senses.ex: Many species of fish reproduce rapidly in the spring months.

senses.def: To cause something to be experienced or known again.
senses.ex: The recording was so clear it seemed to reproduce the live concert atmosphere perfectly.

senses.def: To produce or generate something again, often after a period of absence or dormancy.
senses.ex: After the fire, the forest began to slowly reproduce its diverse plant life.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'program', from French 'programme', from Late Latin 'programma', from Greek 'prógramma' (public notice).

senses.def: To program a computer, machine, or system again or differently, especially to correct errors or update functionality.
senses.ex: The team had to re-program the control panel when the original code proved unstable.

senses.def: To deliberately alter or influence someone's established patterns of thinking or behavior.
senses.ex: He sought therapy to re-program his anxieties about public speaking.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + promote, from Latin prōmoveō ('move forward').

senses.def: To promote someone or something again, especially after a period of demotion or a change in status.
senses.ex: After a successful probationary period, the company decided to re-promote Sarah to team leader.

senses.def: To promote a product or service again, often as part of a new marketing campaign.
senses.ex: The record label will re-promote the album with a series of live performances and interviews.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + proof (adjective, 'impermeable').

senses.def: To treat or coat something again to make it resistant to water or other liquids.
senses.ex: After the first season, the canvas tent needed to be re-proofed against the rain.

senses.def: To test or examine something again to confirm its suitability or effectiveness.
senses.ex: The engineers will re-proof the bridge's structural integrity before allowing heavy traffic.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb propose.

senses.def: To propose something again, especially something that was previously rejected, debated, or requires further consideration; this includes proposing marriage again.
senses.ex: The committee had to re-propose the controversial policy for a second vote after new data emerged.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + provision (from Old French provisioun, from Latin provisio 'foresight, preparation', from providere 'foresee, supply').

senses.def: To supply again with provisions, or to provide anew with conditions or terms.
senses.ex: The explorers had to re-provision their ship before sailing into uncharted waters, while the board agreed to re-provision the contract with updated safety clauses.

etymology: From re- 'again' + purchase.

senses.def: To buy back something previously sold or owned, or to buy something again after it has been used or consumed.
senses.ex: Having lost it in a divorce settlement, he was thrilled to re-purchase his childhood home.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'qualify'. 'Qualify' comes from Middle English 'qualifien', from Old French 'qualifier', from Late Latin 'qualificare', from Latin 'qualis' (of what kind).

senses.def: To meet the necessary requirements or standards for something again, especially after a period of disqualification or due to new regulations.
senses.ex: She had to re-qualify as a doctor after her license expired and new certification rules were implemented.

senses.def: To reassert or modify a previous statement, often for clarity or to avoid misunderstanding.
senses.ex: He needed to re-qualify his earlier position on the budget after hearing the latest economic forecasts.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + raffle, from Middle English raffle, from Old French raffle 'gambling, game of chance', from rafler 'to seize, plunder', of Germanic origin.

senses.def: To conduct a raffle again, especially after an initial attempt was unsatisfactory or invalid.
senses.ex: The organizers decided to re-raffle the grand prize when it became clear the first ticket drawn was ineligible.

etymology: From re- (prefix indicating repetition or a return to a former state) + read (verb).

senses.def: To read something again, especially to check details, deepen understanding, or interpret it in a new way.
senses.ex: He had to re-read the passage several times to grasp its complex argument.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb record.

senses.def: To make a new recording of something, or to record it again to improve its quality or correct an error.
senses.ex: The director asked the actor to re-record the scene because of background noise.

etymology: From re- (prefix indicating repetition) + referral, from Old French 'referer', from Latin 'referre' (to carry back, bring back, report).

senses.def: The act of referring someone or something again to a person or body for consideration or action.
senses.ex: The manager's decision resulted in a re-referral of the customer's complaint to a higher department.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + register (verb).

senses.def: To register something again, or to enter it anew in an official list or record, especially after it has been removed or its status has changed.
senses.ex: The charity had to re-register with the authorities after a change in its governing body.

etymology: From re- + registration, from register (verb), from Old French registrer, from Medieval Latin registrare, from Latin regesta 'things recorded', from regere 'to rule, guide'.

senses.def: The act or process of registering again, especially after a period of inactivity or a change in status.
senses.ex: The airline requires re-registration of frequent flyer accounts that have been inactive for over a year.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'regulare' (to regulate).

senses.def: To introduce or reintroduce regulations on something, particularly after a period of deregulation or a lack of oversight.
senses.ex: Following the market instability, the legislature voted to re-regulate the financial industry.

etymology: From 're-' meaning 'again' + 'release', from Old French 'releser' (to release, set free), from Vulgar Latin '*relaxare' (to loosen, relax).

senses.def: To make a product, such as a film, album, or book, available to the public again after it has been previously issued, or to set someone or something free after a period of confinement.
senses.ex: The company announced plans to re-release the popular video game with updated graphics and additional content.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb rig 'to fit with rigging'.

senses.def: To rig, equip, or alter rigging again, often to repair, modify, or improve functionality.
senses.ex: The sailors had to re-rig the ship's sails after the strong winds tore them.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + roof (verb).

senses.def: To put a new roof on a building, or to cover it with roofing material again.
senses.ex: The old house needed to be re-roofed before winter set in, so they hired a crew to install new shingles.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again, back' + route, from Middle English 'route', from Old French 'route' (way, path), from Latin 'rupta' (broken up, paved road).

senses.def: To change the course or direction of something, such as traffic, a shipment, data, or a person, sending it along a different path or to a different destination.
senses.ex: The unexpected detour required the bus driver to re-rout the entire afternoon schedule.

etymology: From prefix re- + route, from Middle English route, from Old French rote (path, way), of Germanic origin.

senses.def: To change the course, direction, or flow of something, such as traffic, a journey, data, or resources, often to bypass an obstacle or redirect it to a different destination.
senses.ex: Due to the construction, the bus company had to re-route all services away from the city center.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + run.

senses.def: To perform, operate, broadcast, or show again.
senses.ex: The pilot had to re-run the engine diagnostics after the unexpected warning light.

senses.def: An instance or performance of something (such as a race, broadcast, or event) being done or shown again.
senses.ex: After the initial failure, the team planned a re-run of the experiment with modified parameters.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'scale' (to measure or size).

senses.def: To adjust the size, extent, or proportions of something again, often to fit new requirements or to represent it on a different basis.
senses.ex: The engineers had to re-scale the bridge design after discovering unexpected geological pressures.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + schedule. Schedule derives from Middle English 'cedule', from Old French 'cedule', from Late Latin 'schedula' ('small strip of paper'), diminutive of Latin 'scheda' ('strip of papyrus').

senses.def: To change the planned time or date for an event or activity, often because of a conflict or unforeseen circumstance.
senses.ex: Due to the airline's mechanical issues, passengers had to re-schedule their flights for the next day.

etymology: From prefix re- (indicating repetition) + seal (verb).

senses.def: To seal something again, especially after it has been opened or to ensure its security.
senses.ex: The inspector carefully re-sealed the package after verifying its contents.

etymology: From prefix 're-' (again) + verb 'secure' (from Latin 'securus', meaning 'safe, secure').

senses.def: To secure something again, making it safe, protected, or in one's possession once more.
senses.ex: The team worked diligently to re-secure the breached perimeter before nightfall.

etymology: From prefix 're-' (again) + verb 'see'.

senses.def: To see or re-examine something again, or to view it from a new perspective.
senses.ex: After decades of academic study, she returned to the original manuscript to re-see its profound implications.

etymology: From Middle English 'redisede', from 're-' (prefix meaning 'again') + 'sede' (seed, to sow).

senses.def: To plant seeds again, especially in an area where they have been lost or where more growth is desired, or to reinitialize a process by introducing a starting value.
senses.ex: Farmers often re-seed fields after a harsh winter to ensure a good harvest.

etymology: From the prefix 're-' (meaning 'again') and the noun 'selection' (the act of choosing).

senses.def: The act of choosing again or the process of being chosen again, often resulting in a new or subsequent selection.
senses.ex: Following the budget cuts, the department had to undertake a thorough re-selection of its research projects.

etymology: From re- + sell. From Middle English sellen, from Old English sellan (“to give, hand over, sell”), from Proto-Germanic *sellaną (“to give, hand over”), from Proto-Indo-European *selh₁- (“to take, grasp, hand over”).

senses.def: To sell something again, especially after having previously acquired it, or to sell it on behalf of another.
senses.ex: He decided to re-sell the concert tickets he had bought earlier.

etymology: From re- 'again' + sentence.

senses.def: To impose a new or revised sentence on someone who has already been sentenced, typically following an appeal, a successful challenge, or a correction of a procedural error.
senses.ex: After the appeal overturned the original penalty, the judge had to re-sentence the defendant.

etymology: From Middle English 'resetten', from Old French 'receter' (to hide, to receive back), from 're-' + 'ceter' (to receive). The sense of 'setting again' or 'establishing anew' developed later, influenced by the prefix 're-' and the verb 'set'.

senses.def: To adjust, arrange, or position something again or in a new way, especially after it has been disturbed, malfunctioned, or to establish a new starting point.
senses.ex: The technician had to re-set the complex machinery after the error code appeared.

senses.def: To return a broken or dislocated bone to its proper anatomical position.
senses.ex: The surgeon skillfully re-set the fractured wrist during the procedure.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + settle (verb). First attested in the 17th century.

senses.def: To establish oneself or a group in a new place or situation, or to return to a previous place or situation, especially after displacement or disruption.
senses.ex: The refugees worked hard to re-settle their lives in the new country.

etymology: From re- (prefix indicating repetition or intensification) + shape (verb).

senses.def: To change the form, structure, or character of something, often for improvement, adaptation, or influence.
senses.ex: The government aims to re-shape the economy by investing in renewable energy.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + shoot (verb).

senses.def: To film or photograph something again, or to shoot something again, especially because the first attempt was unsatisfactory or an animal needs to be dispatched.
senses.ex: The director ordered the scene to be re-shot because of technical difficulties with the camera.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'show'.

senses.def: To show something again, especially after it has been hidden or removed.
senses.ex: The magician asked the audience to close their eyes before he would re-show the vanished coin.

senses.def: To present a film, play, or other performance for a second or subsequent time.
senses.ex: The cinema announced that they would re-show the classic film next weekend due to popular demand.

etymology: From the prefix 're-' (again) combined with the verb 'shuffle', meaning to move things around, mix cards, or change position.

senses.def: To shuffle again, especially to rearrange items, people, or a deck of cards; to make significant changes to the structure or organization of something.
senses.ex: The manager had to re-shuffle the team roster after several players fell ill.

etymology: From Middle English re- (prefix meaning 'again') + sign (verb), ultimately from Latin signum 'sign'.

senses.def: To sign a document, contract, or other item again, or to extend or renew a previous signature or agreement, especially by signing a new contract.
senses.ex: The veteran quarterback decided to re-sign with his team for another season, much to the fans' delight.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + silver (verb, 'to coat with silver').

senses.def: To apply a layer of silver or a silver-like coating to something again, especially after a previous coating has worn off or tarnished.
senses.ex: The restoration expert meticulously re-silvered the ornate picture frames.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + sit (verb).

senses.def: To sit down again, or to take an examination or test again, typically after failing it the first time.
senses.ex: He decided to re-sit the entrance exam after realizing he had not prepared adequately.

etymology: From 're-' (prefix indicating repetition or reversal) + 'size' (dimensions, scale).

senses.def: To change the dimensions, scale, or fit of something.
senses.ex: You may need to re-size the digital image before uploading it to the website.

etymology: From 're-' (prefix indicating repetition or reversal) + 'skill' (ability to do something well). First attested in the 20th century, gaining prominence with discussions of workforce adaptation.

senses.def: To train or equip someone with new skills, or to acquire them, especially for a different job or to adapt to new requirements.
senses.ex: The government initiated a program to re-skill workers displaced by automation.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + slate (verb, 'to cover with slate' or 'to set down in writing').

senses.def: To cover something, especially a roof, with slate tiles again, or to add or change items on a list, agenda, or schedule, or to present or schedule something again.
senses.ex: After the storm damage, the homeowners had to re-slate the roof and re-slate the entire year's meeting agenda.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb sort.

senses.def: To sort something again, typically because a previous sorting was incorrect or new criteria have been established.
senses.ex: After finding several misplaced files, she had to re-sort the entire cabinet.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'specify' (from Latin 'specificare', from 'species' 'kind, sort' + 'facere' 'to make').

senses.def: To specify something again, or to modify a previous specification, often to clarify, correct, or change it, particularly in technical contexts such as computing.
senses.ex: The client requested that we re-specify the project's parameters to better align with market trends.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + spray (verb).

senses.def: To apply a spray coating to something a second time, such as a coat of paint or protective finish.
senses.ex: Once the base coat had dried, they re-sprayed the furniture with a glossy sealant.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'stage' (a platform for performance; a specific phase or step).

senses.def: To perform or present a play, opera, or other work again, or to recreate a past event or situation, often with a new interpretation or in a simulated context.
senses.ex: The theater company will re-stage the beloved musical with an entirely new cast and set design.

senses.def: To mentally review or simulate a past event, argument, or action.
senses.ex: She would often re-stage their last conversation, trying to understand his perspective.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + start (verb).

senses.def: To begin or cause to begin again after stopping or being interrupted.
senses.ex: We will re-start the discussion after lunch.

etymology: From re- + state. From Middle English 'staten', from Old French 'estat', from Latin 'status' ('a standing, position, condition').

senses.def: To say or express something again, often with more detail or a different emphasis, to ensure understanding or to correct a previous statement.
senses.ex: The witness had to re-state the key events of the evening for the jury.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + stock (verb, 'to supply with goods, provisions').

senses.def: To replenish a supply of goods, items, or provisions that have been used or depleted.
senses.ex: After the holiday rush, the store worked late into the night to re-stock all its empty shelves.

etymology: From re- 'again' + structure, from Middle English, from Old French structure, from Latin structura, from struere 'to build'.

senses.def: To change the organization, composition, or framework of something, typically for improved function or efficiency.
senses.ex: The government announced plans to re-structure the national healthcare system.

etymology: From prefix re- ('again') + style.

senses.def: To change the style or appearance of something again, such as hair, clothing, or a product, often to make it more modern or appealing.
senses.ex: The interior designer was hired to re-style the outdated hotel lobby with a more contemporary aesthetic.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + submit. Submit derives from Old French soumettre, from Latin submittere, meaning 'to lower, yield, send under', from sub- ('under') + mittere ('to send').

senses.def: To submit something or oneself again for consideration, judgment, or approval, especially after a previous attempt was unsuccessful or unsatisfactory.
senses.ex: The researchers had to resubmit their paper for peer review after addressing the editor's concerns.

etymology: From re- 'again' + surface.

senses.def: To come or bring back to the surface after being submerged or hidden.
senses.ex: The submarine was ordered to re-surface immediately after the sonar contact.

senses.def: To become visible or known again after a period of absence or obscurity.
senses.ex: After years of silence, the controversial politician decided to re-surface in the media.

senses.def: To apply a new surface to something, such as a road or a sports field.
senses.ex: The council plans to re-surface the main road through town next spring.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + suspend, from Latin suspendere 'hang up, affix'.

senses.def: To suspend something again after it has been previously un-suspended or removed from suspension.
senses.ex: The committee voted to re-suspend the controversial policy pending further review.

senses.def: To cause a person or group to be suspended again from a position, activity, or privilege.
senses.ex: After violating the terms of his probation, the athlete was re-suspended from the league.

senses.def: To cause a substance or particle to be suspended in a fluid again.
senses.ex: The vigorous shaking was necessary to re-suspend the sediment in the solution.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + take (verb).

senses.def: To capture or seize something again after losing control of it.
senses.ex: The army fought valiantly to re-take the strategically important bridge.

senses.def: To perform or film something again, especially because the first attempt was unsatisfactory.
senses.ex: The director decided to re-take the scene after the actor missed his cue.

senses.def: To take something back or away again.
senses.ex: Please re-take the package you accidentally left on the counter.

etymology: From Middle English 'retellen', from 're-' (again) + 'tell' (to narrate).

senses.def: To narrate a story, event, or experience again, often with variations or for a different audience.
senses.ex: The narrator was asked to re-tell the fairy tale with a modern twist.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + test (verb).

senses.def: To test something or someone again, often to verify a previous result or to check for changes.
senses.ex: We will re-test the software after applying the latest patch.

etymology: From re- (prefix indicating repetition or intensification) + think.

senses.def: To consider something again, especially with the intention of changing a decision, opinion, or approach.
senses.ex: Facing unexpected challenges, the team had to re-think their entire project strategy.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + tighten (verb).

senses.def: To tighten something again, or tighten it more.
senses.ex: After the initial setup, he had to re-tighten the bolts on the new bookshelf.

senses.def: To make a rule, control, or grip more severe or strict after a period of relaxation.
senses.ex: Following the security breach, the company decided to re-tighten its access protocols.

etymology: From prefix re- + tile (verb), ultimately from Old French tiler, from Latin tegula.

senses.def: To cover a surface with new tiles, typically a roof or a room.
senses.ex: After years of wear and tear, the roofer had to re-tile the entire south-facing slope of the house.

etymology: From 're-' (prefix meaning 'again') + 'time' (verb, to set the duration or interval of).

senses.def: To adjust, reschedule, or synchronize the timing of something again, especially to optimize performance, align with other events, or improve efficiency.
senses.ex: The director decided to re-time the film's release to avoid competing with the blockbuster sequel.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'title' (name, designation).

senses.def: To give a new title or designation to something, such as a work of art, a publication, a position, or a role.
senses.ex: The film studio decided to re-title the classic movie for its anniversary re-release.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + tool (verb, 'to equip with tools').

senses.def: To equip or re-equip a factory, workshop, or other facility with new tools or machinery, especially to adapt it for a new purpose.
senses.ex: The company decided to re-tool its assembly line to produce electric vehicles instead of gasoline cars.

senses.def: To acquire new skills or knowledge, or to adapt one's existing abilities, to meet new demands or perform different tasks.
senses.ex: Many professionals are finding it necessary to re-tool their skill sets in response to rapid technological advancements.

etymology: From re- (Latin prefix 'again') + touch (Old English 'tōcan').

senses.def: To touch something or someone again; to make fresh contact, either physically or figuratively by revisiting a topic or adding minor improvements to a work.
senses.ex: The conservator will re-touch the faded sections of the mural with a delicate brush.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + trace (verb).

senses.def: To trace or follow again, especially a path or route.
senses.ex: The hikers decided to re-trace their steps to find the lost compass.

senses.def: To recall or describe again the events or details of something.
senses.ex: The witness was asked to re-trace the sequence of events leading up to the incident.

senses.def: To draw or form again, or to add further lines to.
senses.ex: She had to re-trace the outline of the drawing to make it darker.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + train (verb, 'to teach or instruct').

senses.def: To train or teach someone again, or to modify existing training with new skills, data, or parameters.
senses.ex: After the company restructured, employees needed to re-train for their updated roles using the new software.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (again) + 'transmittere' (to send across).

senses.def: To send or pass on information, signals, or a disease again, especially after receiving it or if the initial transmission was unsuccessful.
senses.ex: The station will re-transmit the broadcast at noon for those who missed it.

etymology: From re- 'again' + trial.

senses.def: A second or new instance of a legal case, competition, or examination, often following an unsuccessful or inconclusive first attempt.
senses.ex: The judge ordered a re-trial after discovering new evidence that cast doubt on the original verdict.

etymology: From the prefix 're-' (meaning 'again') + 'trigger' (verb, to set off or activate).

senses.def: To cause a process, mechanism, or reaction to start or become active again after a period of inactivity or cessation.
senses.ex: The sudden drop in temperature caused the thermostat to re-trigger the heating system.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb try.

senses.def: To make another attempt at doing something, especially after failing or encountering difficulty.
senses.ex: She decided to re-try the difficult piano piece after practicing more.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + tune (verb).

senses.def: To adjust or modify something, especially a musical instrument or electronic device, to a new or correct pitch or frequency.
senses.ex: The orchestra had to re-tune their instruments before the second movement of the symphony.

senses.def: To adapt or adjust one's behavior, attitude, or expectations to a new situation or environment.
senses.ex: After the unexpected promotion, she had to re-tune her expectations for her daily work life.

etymology: From re- (prefix indicating repetition or renewal) + turf (noun, 'grass and the soil that binds its roots').

senses.def: To cover an area, such as a sports field or lawn, with new turf or sod.
senses.ex: The groundskeepers worked quickly to re-turf the damaged sections of the soccer pitch.

etymology: From re- 'again' + union, from Old French union, from Latin uniō, from unus 'one'.

senses.def: The act or process of bringing back together people or things that were separated or estranged.
senses.ex: After years apart, the siblings looked forward to their joyful re-union at the family reunion.

senses.def: A second or new union, especially a marriage, after a previous separation or divorce.
senses.ex: Their re-union was a testament to their enduring love and commitment to each other.

senses.def: An event where people who have not seen each other for a long time come together again, such as former classmates or members of a group.
senses.ex: The annual alumni re-union filled the old gymnasium with laughter and shared memories.

etymology: From re- 'again' + unite, from Middle English unite, from Old French unite, from Latin unitus, past participle of unire 'to join together', from unus 'one'.

senses.def: To join or come together again after being separated or divided.
senses.ex: The long-lost friends were overjoyed to re-unite at the airport terminal.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + upholster (verb), from Middle English upholsterer 'upholsterer', from Old French opo(u)strer 'to furnish, equip'.

senses.def: To put new upholstery on (a chair, sofa, etc.) or repair the existing upholstery.
senses.ex: The antique armchair was sent to the specialist to be re-upholstered in a rich velvet.

etymology: From re- + uptake.

senses.def: The process of reabsorbing or repossessing something, especially the reabsorption of a neurotransmitter into a neuron after its release into the synaptic cleft.
senses.ex: Selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors block this natural process to alleviate depression.

etymology: From re- + use, from Middle English *usen*, from Old French *user*, from Latin *ūsus*, past participle of *ūtī* 'to use'.

senses.def: To use something again, or to use it for a different purpose.
senses.ex: We should always try to re-use materials rather than discarding them.

etymology: From re- + vamp, from Middle English vampe, originally meaning to patch or mend (a shoe), of uncertain origin. The sense evolved to a broader renovation or modernization.

senses.def: To renovate, improve, or modernize something, giving it new energy or vigor, such as a building, plan, performance, or even an abstract concept like confidence.
senses.ex: The marketing team will re-vamp the campaign to better appeal to younger consumers.

etymology: From Old French reveoir 'to see again', from Latin revidere, from re- 'back' + videre 'to see'.

senses.def: A formal assessment of something, typically a performance or work, with an evaluation of its merits.
senses.ex: The critic's review of the new play was overwhelmingly positive.

senses.def: An act of reviewing; a re-examination or reconsideration.
senses.ex: The committee will conduct a thorough review of the company's financial records.

senses.def: A survey or summary of previous work on a subject.
senses.ex: Her literature review synthesized the key findings from decades of research.

senses.def: To examine or assess something formally with the possibility or intention of instituting change if necessary.
senses.ex: The manager decided to review the current procedures for handling customer complaints.

senses.def: To look back on or think about past events.
senses.ex: He sat by the fire, reviewing the events of his long and eventful life.

etymology: Latin 're-' (again) + 'visio' (sight, seeing), from 'videre' (to see).

senses.def: The act of looking at, examining, or considering something again, often with the intent to improve or understand it better; a revised or re-examined version.
senses.ex: The committee requested a re-vision of the proposal to address environmental concerns.

senses.def: A reappearance or fresh perception of something.
senses.ex: She had a sudden re-vision of her childhood home, years after leaving.

etymology: From re- 'again' + visit. First attested in the early 17th century.

senses.def: To consider, discuss, or examine something again, especially after a period of time has passed.
senses.ex: The committee decided to revisit the proposal after receiving new data from the research team.

senses.def: To visit a place again.
senses.ex: She planned to revisit her childhood home during her summer vacation.

senses.def: To return to a particular subject or topic in thought or discussion.
senses.ex: He often found himself revisiting the same anxieties whenever he thought about the future.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb walk.

senses.def: To walk over a path or route again.
senses.ex: The hikers decided to re-walk the scenic trail they had enjoyed the previous day.

senses.def: To re-examine or reconsider a process, decision, or experience by mentally retracing the steps involved.
senses.ex: Before the final presentation, she needed to re-walk the entire project timeline to identify potential issues.

etymology: From prefix re- + wash. From Middle English waschen, from Old English wæscan, from Proto-Germanic *wōskōną.

senses.def: To wash something again, whether to correct an inadequate initial wash or as a ritual act.
senses.ex: The housekeeper had to re-wash the tablecloth after the wine stain reappeared.

etymology: From 're-' (again) + 'weigh' (to measure mass).

senses.def: To weigh something again, often to verify a previous measurement or to account for changes.
senses.ex: The inspector had to re-weigh the package after adding the extra packing material.

senses.def: In finance, to revalue assets or liabilities, especially after a change in market conditions or accounting standards.
senses.ex: The company decided to re-weigh its investment portfolio to reflect the new economic climate.

etymology: From re- +‎ wire.

senses.def: To install new wiring or replace existing wiring, or metaphorically, to alter neural connections to change a response or behavior.
senses.ex: The electricians will re-wire the old house, while therapists help patients re-wire their brains to manage stress.

etymology: From prefix re- ('again') + word.

senses.def: To alter or express something again in different words, in order to clarify, improve, or change the original meaning or impact.
senses.ex: The editor had to re-word the sentence to make the subtle irony more apparent.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + work (verb).

senses.def: To alter, adapt, or improve upon existing material, work, or structure, often to correct faults, enhance quality, or repurpose it.
senses.ex: The team had to re-work the entire software module after discovering critical bugs.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + working (present participle of work).

senses.def: The process of modifying, improving, or reprocessing something previously made, or materials, to make it usable or better, or the result of this process.
senses.ex: The meticulous re-working of the old engine made it run as if it were brand new.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + verb wrap.

senses.def: To wrap something again, either because it was previously unwrapped or to use new wrapping material.
senses.ex: He had to re-wrap the package after the delivery driver dropped it.

etymology: From re- (prefix meaning 'again') + write. Middle English writen, from Old English wrītan.

senses.def: To write something again, especially to improve, alter, or adapt it for a different purpose or audience.
senses.ex: The playwright had to re-write the final act after the test audience gave negative feedback.

etymology: From re- 'again' + absorb. First attested in the early 17th century.

senses.def: To absorb again something that has been previously absorbed or eliminated.
senses.ex: The kidneys reabsorb essential minerals and water from the filtrate.

senses.def: To incorporate or assimilate something new into an existing system or structure.
senses.ex: The company hopes to reabsorb the smaller startup into its main division.

senses.def: To take back into oneself or one's own substance or being.
senses.ex: After the argument, she tried to reabsorb her harsh words and mend the relationship.

etymology: From re- + absorption.

senses.def: The act or process of absorbing something again, or the state of being absorbed again; this can refer to physical substances, biological materials, or economic elements being drawn back into a system or source.
senses.ex: The body's efficient reabsorption of water in the kidneys is vital for maintaining fluid balance.

etymology: Middle English reche, from Old English rǣcan ‘extend, offer, impute’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch reiken and German reichen.

senses.def: To extend one's arm or hand in a particular direction.
senses.ex: He reached out to steady himself against the wall.

senses.def: To arrive at or get as far as a particular place or point.
senses.ex: The train will reach its destination by midnight.

senses.def: To achieve or attain a desired level, position, or result.
senses.ex: She finally reached the top of her profession after years of hard work.

senses.def: The extent or range of what can be perceived, understood, or achieved.
senses.ex: The new telescope has a viewing range far beyond our previous reach.

senses.def: An act of extending one's arm or hand to grasp or touch something.
senses.ex: With a quick reach, the cat knocked the vase off the table.

etymology: From the verb phrase 'reach me down', referring to items being taken down from a shelf for a customer.

senses.def: A garment, especially clothing, that is ready-made and sold from stock, rather than being made to order; or, by extension, something that is readily available and passed on or easily influenced.
senses.ex: She preferred to buy her suits as reach-me-downs, finding them more affordable than custom tailoring.

etymology: From Middle English 'rechen', from Old English 'rǣcan' ('to stretch out, extend, offer'), from Proto-Germanic '*raikōną'.

senses.def: The action or process of extending one's arm or hand to grasp or touch something, or extending one's influence, power, or effect.
senses.ex: Her excited reaching for the prize brought cheers from the crowd.

etymology: From re- (again) + acquaint. Acquaint derives from Old French acointer, from a prefix 'to' + coint 'known'.

senses.def: To make or become familiar again with a person, place, or thing, especially after a period of absence or disuse.
senses.ex: She spent a week reacquainting herself with the complex workflow of the department.

etymology: From re- + acquire. From Middle English acqueren, from Old French aquerre, from Vulgar Latin *acquīrere, alteration of Latin adquīrere, from ad- ‘to’ + quaerere ‘to seek, ask’.

senses.def: To get something back, such as possession, a skill, or control, after it has been lost, given away, or relinquished.
senses.ex: After years of legal battles, she finally reacquired her ancestral home.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (back) + 'agere' (to do, drive). First attested in the 17th century.

senses.def: To respond to a stimulus, influence, or event by taking action, often in a way that is different from a neutral or passive state, including undergoing a chemical or physical change.
senses.ex: The audience reacted with cheers and applause to the band's surprise appearance on stage.

etymology: Coined in the 20th century, from English 'react' + '-ance'. 'React' derives from Latin 're-' (back, again) + 'agere' (to do, drive, act).

senses.def: Resistance to external influence, control, or proposals, especially when one's autonomy is perceived as threatened.
senses.ex: When his parents tried to dictate his career path, his inherent reactance surfaced, and he began exploring entirely different fields.

etymology: From Latin 're-' (back) + 'agere' (to do, drive) + '-ant' (agent suffix). First attested in the early 20th century.

senses.def: A substance or compound that takes part in a chemical reaction.
senses.ex: The experiment involved mixing two clear liquids, which immediately produced a vibrant blue precipitate as the reactants combined.

senses.def: A person or thing that reacts to a stimulus or influence.
senses.ex: She was a passive observer in most situations, but a fierce reactant when her principles were challenged.

etymology: From Medieval Latin rēactiōnem (nominative rēāctiō), from rēactāre 'act back, repeat', from rē- 'back' + agere 'to do, drive'.

senses.def: An action, feeling, statement, or chemical process that occurs in response to a specific event, stimulus, or agent.
senses.ex: Her sharp reaction to the news was a mixture of shock and relief.

senses.def: A movement or tendency that opposes a previous movement or tendency.
senses.ex: The political landscape shifted with a strong public reaction against the proposed policies.

etymology: Coined by Sigmund Freud in 1905, from reaction + formation.

senses.def: In psychology, a defense mechanism in which a person unconsciously replaces an unwanted impulse with its opposite.
senses.ex: His constant boasting about his wealth was a clear reaction-formation against his deep-seated insecurity.

etymology: Compound of reaction + time. First used in the 19th century.

senses.def: The interval between the presentation of a stimulus or event and the initiation of a response, or the duration required for a process to commence after a specific trigger.
senses.ex: The participant's reaction-time to the flashing light was recorded.

etymology: From reaction + -ary. First attested in the 1830s, referring to opposition to the French Revolution.

senses.def: Opposing social or political change or progress and advocating a return to an earlier state.
senses.ex: His reactionary views on the economy were met with widespread disbelief.

senses.def: A person who opposes social or political change and advocates a return to an earlier state.
senses.ex: The committee was infiltrated by a number of influential reactionaries.

etymology: From re- 'again' + activate; from Latin 'activus' (active).

senses.def: To make something active, effective, or functional again, particularly after a period of dormancy, disuse, or suppression; this can apply to substances, memories, emotions, or organizations.
senses.ex: The foundation intends to reactivate its charitable programs in underserved communities.

etymology: From Latin 'reactus', past participle of 'reagere' ('to act back, drive back, reply'), from 're-' ('back') + 'agere' ('to drive, do').

senses.def: Showing or characterized by the tendency to react, often suddenly or unexpectedly.
senses.ex: She was known for her reactive personality, easily angered by minor issues.

senses.def: Happening in response to, or as a result of, a particular situation or event.
senses.ex: The government's reactive approach to the crisis did little to inspire public confidence.

senses.def: Relating to or involving a chemical reaction.
senses.ex: The experiment involved several highly reactive compounds that required careful handling.

etymology: From reactive + -ity. From reactive, from react, from French réagir, from Latin re- ‘back’ + agere ‘to do, drive’.

senses.def: The quality or state of being reactive; the tendency to react to external forces or influences.
senses.ex: Her emotional reactivity often led to misunderstandings with her colleagues.

senses.def: The speed or intensity with which a substance undergoes a chemical reaction.
senses.ex: The increased temperature significantly boosted the compound's reactivity.

etymology: From Middle English 'reactor', from Medieval Latin 'reactor' ('one who acts back'), from Latin 're-' ('back') + 'agere' ('to act').

senses.def: A device or vessel in which a significant process, such as a chemical reaction or a nuclear reaction, is carried out.
senses.ex: Engineers monitored the temperature within the nuclear reactor to prevent overheating.

senses.def: A person or thing that responds quickly or strongly to a stimulus or event.
senses.ex: She proved to be a highly sensitive reactor to the new medication, experiencing immediate side effects.

etymology: Middle English reden, from Old English rǣdan ('advise, interpret, read'), from Proto-Germanic *rōþijanÄ… ('advise, guess, understand').

senses.def: To look at and understand the meaning of written or printed words, symbols, etc.
senses.ex: She sat by the window and read the morning paper.

senses.def: To say aloud the words that are written or printed.
senses.ex: The teacher asked the student to read the passage to the class.

senses.def: To understand or interpret something in a particular way.
senses.ex: I read his silence as a sign of disapproval.

senses.def: To discover or learn about something by reading.
senses.ex: He read that the company was planning to expand.

senses.def: To spend time reading a particular book or type of book.
senses.ex: He read Shakespeare throughout his university years.

etymology: Compound of read (verb) + out (adverb). Developed in the mid-20th century, originally referring to information being 'read out' from a system.

senses.def: Information displayed or reported by a device or system, or the device/screen itself that presents this information.
senses.ex: The technician relied on the precise read-out from the diagnostic equipment to identify the fault.

etymology: From 'readable' (early 17th century) + '-ity'. 'Readable' is derived from Middle English 'redable', from 'reden' (to read) + '-able'.

senses.def: The quality of being easy to read or understand, often assessed through specific metrics or by general clarity.
senses.ex: The editor improved the manuscript's readability by simplifying complex sentences and removing jargon.

etymology: From prefix re- 'again' + adapt, from Latin adaptare 'fit, adjust'.

senses.def: To adjust to a new situation or purpose, especially after a previous period of adaptation or non-adaptation.
senses.ex: Following the accident, he needed time to readapt to daily life and regain his independence.

etymology: From re- + address. First attested in the 17th century.

senses.def: To address someone or something again, especially after a pause or interruption.
senses.ex: The speaker paused to take a sip of water before readdressing the audience.

senses.def: To write a new address on an envelope or package, or to redirect mail or a package to a different address.
senses.ex: Please readdress the parcel to the new office before it is sent out.
